metadata.usage_instructions: Use these statements to guide conversations with students, pose reflective questions, identify areas for improvement, and provide targeted suggestions.

statements.statement: I have personal bests I'm trying to beat when I submit new work

questions: What's your personal best in this subject so far?
How far have you come this year?
What progress can you see?
How do you measure your growth?
suggestions: Compare current work to work from months ago
List skills you've gained this term

statements.statement: I have a clear idea of what I need to know in order to understand everything well, so I ask the teacher to clarify tasks that I'm not 100% clear on

negative: proceeds with tasks without full understanding

questions: What's your approach when a teacher explains something and you don't quite get it?
How easy or difficult do you find it to ask for clarification in front of others?
Can you think of a time asking a question really helped you understand something better?
suggestions: If you're unsure about a task, try pinpointing exactly what part is confusing. It's easier to ask a specific question than a general one.
Remember, asking for clarification is a sign of engagement and wanting to learn, not a weakness. Teachers appreciate it!

statements.statement: I have personal bests I'm trying to beat when I submit new work

questions: What's your personal best in this subject so far?
How far have you come this year?
What progress can you see?
How do you measure your growth?
suggestions: Compare current work to work from months ago
List skills you've gained this term

statements.statement: I have a clear idea of what I need to know in order to understand everything well, so I ask the teacher to clarify tasks that I'm not 100% clear on

questions: Do you feel comfortable asking questions when you're unsure?
What stops you from seeking clarification when needed?
How do you identify what you don't understand?
suggestions: Write down questions as they occur to you during lessons
Practice asking for clarification - it shows engagement, not weakness

statements.statement: I have begun researching how other people got to where they were

questions: Who inspires you in your field of interest?
Have you looked into how successful people in your area achieved their goals?
What career paths are you curious about?
suggestions: Research one person per week who succeeded in your area of interest
Watch interviews or read biographies of people you admire

statements.statement: I have imagined what a good set of exam results look like for me. I have written them down somewhere, like a commitment to myself

questions: Have you written down your target grades?
What would your ideal exam results look like?
Where do you keep your academic goals?
suggestions: Write your target grades and put them somewhere visible
Create a vision board or document with your academic goals

statements.statement: I have mental lists of things I hope for, from small to big academic achievements

questions: What small academic wins are you working towards?
What's your biggest academic aspiration?
How do you keep track of your goals?
suggestions: Create a 'achievement ladder' from small daily wins to big goals
Celebrate small victories as steps toward larger achievements

statements.statement: I have started to find out about current affairs by reading a news site, watching TV news or choosing a documentary to watch

questions: How do you stay informed about what's happening in the world?
What news sources do you find most interesting?
How might current events relate to your studies?
suggestions: Spend 10 minutes daily reading news relevant to your subjects
Watch one documentary per week related to your studies

statements.statement: I have thought about what good work looks like, and I'm aware of that as I work

questions: How do you define 'good work' in your subjects?
What makes the difference between average and excellent work?
Do you have examples of excellent work to guide you?
suggestions: Collect examples of high-quality work to use as models
Before starting, visualize what excellent work would look like

statements.statement: I know why school is important to me - I have thought it through, maybe even written it down

questions: Why is your education important to you personally?
How does school connect to your future goals?
Have you written down your 'why' for studying?
suggestions: Write a personal mission statement for your education
Reflect on how each subject connects to your future goals

statements.statement: I like to ask questions for clarification in lessons and make contributions such as volunteering answers or offering opinions

questions: What holds you back from participating in class?
How comfortable are you with asking questions?
When did you last volunteer an answer in class?
suggestions: Set a goal to ask one question per lesson
Prepare one comment or opinion before each class

statements.statement: I often have another class member I compete against

questions: Do you have a study buddy or friendly rival?
How does healthy competition motivate you?
Who in your class pushes you to do better?
suggestions: Find a study partner with similar goals for friendly competition
Use peer success as motivation, not intimidation

statements.statement: I often talk to my friends about my subjects, going over complicated topics or sharing enthusiasms

questions: Do you discuss your subjects with friends?
How does talking about topics help your understanding?
What subjects excite you enough to share with others?
suggestions: Start a study group for your most challenging subject
Share one interesting thing you learned each day with a friend

statements.statement: I seek extra material (textbooks, articles, handouts, revision sites) to deepen my understanding of a topic

questions: What extra resources have you found helpful?
How do you find additional learning materials?
What topics would you like to explore more deeply?
suggestions: Ask teachers for recommended reading lists
Explore one new resource per week for your challenging subjects

statements.statement: I set targets, like a grade or a certain type of feedback, to work towards

questions: What specific targets are you working towards?
How do you decide what targets to set?
What type of feedback are you aiming for?
suggestions: Set SMART targets for each subject
Focus on process goals as well as grade goals

statements.statement: I take an interest in certain careers or courses and seek out video clips or online articles about them, just to see if they might be for me

questions: What careers have you been exploring?
How do you research potential career paths?
What courses or universities interest you?
suggestions: Watch one career-focused video per week
Create a folder of interesting career resources

statements.statement: I try and get involved in school life, joining clubs, helping others and building relationships that will help me as I go along

questions: What clubs or activities are you involved in?
How do you build helpful relationships at school?
What opportunities might you be missing?
suggestions: Join one new club or activity this term
Volunteer for a school event to meet new people

statements.statement: I want teachers to say good things about me at parents' evenings, and work to make sure those things are more likely to happen

questions: What would you like teachers to say about you?
How do you build positive relationships with teachers?
What impression do you think you give?
suggestions: Act on feedback to show you're listening
Thank teachers for their help to build positive relationships

statements.statement: I'm happy to watch a film or read a book-chapter connected to my learning so I can find out more and make connections

questions: What films or books have enhanced your understanding?
How do you make connections between different sources?
What subject would you like to explore through film or literature?
suggestions: Ask teachers for film/book recommendations for each topic
Keep a log of connections between different sources

statements.statement: If the teacher suggests an out-of-class activity or opportunity, I consider it

questions: What opportunities have you taken recently?
How do you decide which activities to pursue?
What's stopped you from taking certain opportunities?
suggestions: Say yes to at least one opportunity per term
Ask teachers about upcoming opportunities

statements.statement: My attendance and punctuality are very good, and I work to maintain them

questions: How do you ensure good attendance and punctuality?
What impact does attendance have on your learning?
What challenges affect your attendance?
suggestions: Set multiple alarms to ensure punctuality
Track your attendance and set improvement goals

statements.statement: When entering a lesson, I'm focussed and immediately look for the starter task

questions: How do you prepare yourself before entering a lesson?
What helps you focus at the start of class?
What distracts you when entering a lesson?
suggestions: Arrive 2 minutes early to prepare mentally
Review previous lesson notes before entering

statements.statement: I can increase periods of concentration if I have to - I know what my main distractions are, and how to turn them off so I can focus

questions: What are your main distractions when studying?
How long can you concentrate before needing a break?
What strategies help you maintain focus?
suggestions: Use the Pomodoro Technique for focused study sessions
Create a distraction list to capture thoughts without acting on them

statements.statement: I challenge myself when studying topics which I am not familiar with, working harder to understand them and revisiting them for checks more often

questions: How do you approach topics you find difficult?
When do you revisit challenging material?
What's your strategy for understanding new concepts?
suggestions: Schedule extra time for difficult topics
Break challenging topics into smaller, manageable parts

statements.statement: I complete draft-work in advance and ask the teacher to take a quick look at it so I can make any changes before the real deadline

questions: Do you create drafts before final submissions?
How comfortable are you showing incomplete work to teachers?
When do you typically start assignments?
suggestions: Aim to complete drafts at least 3 days before deadlines
Ask teachers when they're available for draft reviews

statements.statement: I don't mind putting in some work over the weekend reviewing difficult work or going through a study guide or website to stay on top of things

questions: How do you use weekends for academic work?
What's your weekend study routine?
How do you balance rest and study on weekends?
suggestions: Dedicate 2-3 hours on weekends for review and catch-up
Use Sunday evenings to prepare for the week ahead

statements.statement: I generally know in advance what I plan to achieve in a study session rather than start it and just hope

questions: How do you plan your study sessions?
What makes a study session successful for you?
Do you set specific goals before studying?
suggestions: Write 3 objectives before each study session
Review whether you met your goals after studying

statements.statement: I go over work one last time before handing it in, just to check it's as good as I can make it

questions: What's your final check process before submitting work?
How do you ensure quality in your submissions?
What mistakes do you commonly catch when reviewing?
suggestions: Create a submission checklist for all assignments
Read work aloud to catch errors

statements.statement: I have an out-of-school routine for homework - doing it when I get home, or at the same time each day

questions: What's your homework routine?
When do you find it easiest to complete homework?
How consistent is your study schedule?
suggestions: Establish a fixed homework time each day
Create a ritual to signal the start of homework time

statements.statement: I often ask about the success criteria/requirements of the task so I'm more likely to produce quality work

questions: Do you always understand what's expected in assignments?
How do you clarify task requirements?
What happens when you're unsure about criteria?
suggestions: Ask for rubrics or mark schemes for all assignments
Clarify requirements before starting any task

statements.statement: I often ask myself 'what can I also do?' and create my own extension criteria, aiming to impress my teacher

questions: How do you go beyond basic requirements?
What extensions have you added to recent work?
How do you challenge yourself in assignments?
suggestions: Add one 'wow factor' element to each assignment
Ask teachers what would make work exceptional

statements.statement: I often go looking for problems - seeking out topics I find hard and listing the questions I want to discuss with my teacher

questions: How do you identify areas where you need help?
What questions do you have ready for your teachers?
How do you approach your weak areas?
suggestions: Keep a question journal for each subject
Dedicate time weekly to identify problem areas

statements.statement: I often go the extra mile to complete work to a really high standard, asking myself 'what would this look like if it were excellent?'

questions: What does excellent work mean to you?
How do you push yourself to excel?
When did you last go the extra mile?
suggestions: Before starting, visualize what excellent work looks like
Compare your work to exemplars before submitting

statements.statement: I often try to see the value in the work my teachers set, and explain to myself why it's important, even if I sometimes have to persuade myself

questions: How do you find value in tasks you don't enjoy?
What helps you stay motivated with boring work?
Can you connect every task to a bigger purpose?
suggestions: Write down how each task develops useful skills
Connect boring tasks to your larger goals

statements.statement: I often work without screens, headphones or alerts, switching everything off so it's just me and the task

questions: How often do you work completely distraction-free?
What happens to your productivity without devices?
What's your biggest digital distraction?
suggestions: Try 'airplane mode' study sessions
Use app blockers during study time

statements.statement: I set myself little tasks, like reading over the previous week's notes and try to find the answer to things I don't understand

questions: What small tasks do you set yourself?
How often do you review previous work?
How do you identify what you don't understand?
suggestions: Spend 15 minutes each evening reviewing the day's notes
Create a 'don't understand' list to work through

statements.statement: I sometimes approach teachers and ask for suggestions for additional resources or reading recommendations

questions: When did you last ask a teacher for extra resources?
What stops you from asking for recommendations?
How do you find additional learning materials?
suggestions: Ask each teacher for their 'top 3' resources
Request reading lists at the start of each topic

statements.statement: I speak to teachers or students to check I know what to do before I start, to ensure my effort is targeted wisely

questions: Do you clarify tasks before starting?
How do you ensure your effort is well-directed?
What happens when you misunderstand requirements?
suggestions: Always confirm understanding before leaving class
Check with successful peers about their approach

statements.statement: I watch what higher-achieving students do in class and sometimes steal behaviours from them

questions: What successful behaviors have you noticed in others?
Which classmates inspire better study habits?
What strategies would you like to adopt?
suggestions: Identify one successful behavior to adopt each week
Ask high achievers about their study methods

statements.statement: If I'm given a choice of homeworks, I sometimes do both

questions: How do you approach optional work?
When did you last do extra homework?
What motivates you to go beyond requirements?
suggestions: Try doing both options once per month
Use optional work to explore interests

statements.statement: Sometimes, I look ahead to what we're studying next and do some pre-learning before a lesson so I can arrive with questions

questions: Do you ever study ahead of lessons?
How might pre-learning help you?
What would you gain from arriving prepared?
suggestions: Spend 10 minutes previewing tomorrow's topics
Write down 2 questions before each new topic

statements.statement: When a subject is tough, I try not to ignore it, but put more effort in instead

questions: How do you respond to difficult subjects?
What helps you persist when things get tough?
Which subject needs more of your effort?
suggestions: Allocate extra time to your most challenging subject
Reward yourself for tackling difficult work

statements.statement: I can breakdown in small steps what I need to achieve, and often do things in more than one sitting rather than all at once

questions: How do you break down large tasks?
What's your approach to big projects?
How do you make tasks feel manageable?
suggestions: Use the 'chunk it down' method for all big tasks
Plan tasks across multiple study sessions

statements.statement: I can summarise and reshape information it so it feels like mine. I might re-write it, or use a table, chart, graph or mind-map

questions: How do you make information your own?
What formats work best for your learning?
When do you reshape information?
suggestions: Try a new format each week (mind map, table, etc.)
Rewrite key concepts in your own words

statements.statement: I file my notes in the right place at the end of each day

questions: How do you organize your notes?
What's your end-of-day routine?
How often do you lose important papers?
suggestions: Set a daily alarm for filing time
Use color-coded folders for each subject

statements.statement: I have an organised workspace at home and in school to study, with everything in its place so I can find it quickly

questions: Describe your study space organization
How much time do you waste looking for things?
What would an ideal workspace look like?
suggestions: Dedicate 10 minutes weekly to organizing your space
Create designated spots for all materials

statements.statement: I keep my books and folders in one place in my room/home

questions: Where do you keep your school materials?
How often do you misplace books or folders?
What's your storage system?
suggestions: Designate one specific area for all school materials
Use a shelf or box system for each subject

statements.statement: I know what has been covered so far on my course, and ensure it's all there by checking my books against study websites, textbooks or knowledge organisers

questions: How do you track what you've covered?
Are there gaps in your notes?
How do you ensure complete coverage?
suggestions: Create a checklist of topics for each subject
Regularly audit your notes against the syllabus

statements.statement: I know where everything is all of the time and can access relevant notes during the lesson easily

questions: How quickly can you find specific notes?
What system helps you stay organized?
When do you struggle to find materials?
suggestions: Use dividers and labels in all folders
Keep a contents page for each subject

statements.statement: I look ahead to next week, checking what needs doing so that even when lots of deadlines come at once, I work out how to finish and submit everything

questions: How do you track upcoming deadlines?
What's your weekly planning process?
How do you handle multiple deadlines?
suggestions: Use a weekly planner to visualize all deadlines
Sunday evening planning sessions for the week ahead

statements.statement: I make mini-lists of tasks I have to do at the start of particular periods - like on a Monday, or over a weekend - and think about how to prioritise them

questions: How do you decide what to prioritize?
What list-making system works for you?
When do you plan your tasks?
suggestions: Use the urgent/important matrix for priorities
Start each week with a prioritized task list

statements.statement: I might set reminders for myself - alarms on my phone - or leave notes for myself so I don't forget things

questions: What reminder systems do you use?
How do you ensure you don't forget important tasks?
What works best for your memory?
suggestions: Set recurring reminders for regular tasks
Use sticky notes in visible places

statements.statement: I often list the things I have to do and figure out which order I need to do things to make the best use of my time

questions: How do you decide the order of tasks?
What makes your study time efficient?
When do you feel most productive?
suggestions: Do hardest tasks when energy is highest
Batch similar tasks together

statements.statement: I organise my work visually, maybe using colourful stationery or reminders so that I know how the course works

questions: How do visual elements help your organization?
What color coding systems do you use?
How do you make information visually clear?
suggestions: Assign colors to different subjects or topics
Use highlighters to categorize information types

statements.statement: I pack my bag for the next day the night before

questions: What's your evening preparation routine?
How often do you forget materials?
What would make mornings easier?
suggestions: Create a packing checklist for each day
Set a nightly reminder to pack your bag

statements.statement: I review my notes to ensure they are organised in a beneficial order for revision, sticking in handouts, making a contents page or adding colourful headings

questions: How revision-ready are your notes?
What organizational improvements do you make?
How do you structure notes for easy review?
suggestions: Add contents pages to all subject folders
Use consistent heading styles throughout

statements.statement: I set aside time for study and resist the temptation to watch TV until it's been done

questions: How do you resist distractions?
What helps you prioritize study?
When is your protected study time?
suggestions: Use leisure activities as rewards after studying
Create non-negotiable study blocks

statements.statement: I sometimes make quick daily lists - must finish this, have to do this, get started on this task, etc.

questions: What goes on your daily lists?
How do you categorize daily tasks?
What's your morning planning routine?
suggestions: Use must/should/could categories for daily tasks
Limit daily 'must do' items to 3-5 tasks

statements.statement: I sometimes plan my week in advance, giving myself plenty of time to work on tasks

questions: How do you plan your week?
Do you build in buffer time?
What tools help your weekly planning?
suggestions: Sunday planning sessions for the week
Add 25% extra time to all estimates

statements.statement: I sometimes summarise everything we've learnt on one page, or a series of flash-cards, or a knowledge organiser

questions: How do you consolidate your learning?
What summary formats work best for you?
When do you create overviews?
suggestions: Create one-page summaries after each topic
Use flashcards for key concepts and definitions

statements.statement: I spend small periods of time just double-checking I've done everything I need to or reviewing the last few days

questions: How often do you check your progress?
What's your review routine?
How do you ensure nothing is missed?
suggestions: Daily 5-minute check-ins before bed
Weekly review sessions on Sundays

statements.statement: I work out the best way to present a whole course and reorganise everything so it's clear and helpful for me

questions: How do you organize course content?
What structure works best for your learning?
Have you personalized your notes organization?
suggestions: Create your own course overview document
Reorganize notes to match your learning style

statements.statement: I am not afraid to give a question a go, even if I am not fully sure the method I use on my first attempt will be a success

questions: What stops you from attempting difficult questions?
How do you approach uncertainty in exams?
What happens when you're not sure of the method?
suggestions: Practice 'having a go' with low-stakes questions
Remember: attempting earns more marks than blank spaces

statements.statement: I analyse where I have gone wrong on exam or test questions by going through the feedback or checking a mark scheme

questions: How do you use mark schemes?
What do you do with test feedback?
How do you learn from mistakes?
suggestions: Keep an error log with corrections
Rework questions using mark scheme guidance

statements.statement: I collect exam questions and organise them into groups: topic-by-topic or easy-medium-hard

questions: How do you organize practice questions?
Where do you find exam questions?
How do you track question difficulty?
suggestions: Create question banks for each topic
Label questions by difficulty and time needed

statements.statement: I do past paper questions, often for short intense bursts, dipping in and out like mini-exams

questions: How often do you practice past papers?
What's your approach to exam practice?
How long are your practice sessions?
suggestions: Daily 15-minute past paper sessions
Mix full papers with targeted question practice

statements.statement: I have a go at making my own exam style questions and marking my answers

questions: Have you tried creating your own questions?
How would making questions help you?
What would you test others on?
suggestions: Create 3 questions after each topic
Swap questions with study partners

statements.statement: I have identified my weaker areas of understanding and focused more time on these areas

questions: What are your weakest topics?
How do you identify knowledge gaps?
How much time goes to weak areas?
suggestions: List topics by confidence level
Allocate 60% of revision to weak areas

statements.statement: I know how long each exam is and I am driven to know how long I will need to spend on each section. I time myself on each section to try to work this out

questions: Do you know the timing for all your exams?
How do you practice exam pacing?
Have you timed yourself on practice papers?
suggestions: Create a timing guide for each exam
Practice with a timer for every section

statements.statement: I know the different command words to expect in a test or exam and have listed them so I can revise each one

questions: Can you explain different command words?
How do command words change your answers?
Which command words confuse you?
suggestions: Create a command word glossary with examples
Practice answering the same content with different commands

statements.statement: I know the skills required in exams and tests, often I've practised using a range of unfamiliar data, photos, graphs, maps, questions etc so it doesn't matter if the wording is different on the day or examples are unfamiliar

questions: How do you prepare for unfamiliar questions?
What skills do your exams test?
How confident are you with new data formats?
suggestions: Practice with questions from different exam boards
Work with unfamiliar examples weekly

statements.statement: I know what I need to do with my notes in order to make them fit for retrieval/revision, and I spend time regularly checking I can recall them

questions: How do you test your recall?
What makes notes good for revision?
How often do you practice retrieval?
suggestions: Use the cover-write-check method daily
Transform notes into recall questions

statements.statement: I like looking at model answers to understand how to reach the top of the mark scheme

questions: Where do you find model answers?
What do you learn from exemplars?
How do you apply model answer techniques?
suggestions: Collect A* examples for each question type
Annotate model answers to identify key features

statements.statement: I often lecture my notes out loud from memory as if I were teaching a class, to practice the kind of explanation the exam will require of me

questions: Have you tried teaching content out loud?
How well can you explain topics?
Who could you teach to test understanding?
suggestions: Teach topics to an imaginary class
Record yourself explaining key concepts

statements.statement: I re-use past paper questions, sometimes over and over, until I'm confident

questions: Do you repeat questions you got wrong?
How many times do you practice difficult questions?
What builds your confidence?
suggestions: Create a 'retry pile' for difficult questions
Space repetitions over several days

statements.statement: I seek out additional exam questions and mark schemes, even if they are from different exam boards

questions: Where do you find extra exam questions?
Do you use other exam boards' materials?
How do you expand your question bank?
suggestions: Check 3 different exam boards for each topic
Ask teachers for additional question sources

statements.statement: I set myself timed questions and work under exam conditions even when I don't feel like it

questions: How often do you practice under exam conditions?
What stops you from timed practice?
How do you simulate exam pressure?
suggestions: Weekly timed practice sessions
Start with short timed bursts, build up

statements.statement: I sometimes submit extra work for marking to ensure my teacher gives me a clear steer on how to improve

questions: Have you submitted extra work for feedback?
What stops you from seeking more feedback?
How could extra feedback help you?
suggestions: Submit one extra piece monthly for feedback
Ask teachers what extra work would be helpful

statements.statement: I sometimes try and 'think like an examiner' - imagining what possible questions might come up for a topic and listing them all

questions: Can you predict likely exam questions?
How do you think like an examiner?
What patterns do you see in past questions?
suggestions: List 5 possible questions per topic
Analyze past paper patterns

statements.statement: I will find opportunities to test myself on the knowledge I have gained by covering up information and trying to recall it

questions: How do you test your knowledge?
What self-testing methods work for you?
How often do you practice recall?
suggestions: End each study session with a mini-test
Use flashcards or apps for regular testing

statements.statement: If there are gaps in my knowledge, I know it's my job to find out how to fill them

questions: How do you identify knowledge gaps?
Who's responsible for your learning?
What do you do when you find gaps?
suggestions: Regular knowledge audits against syllabus
Create action plans for filling gaps

statements.statement: When I revise with my friends, we test each other rather than just copy each other's notes

questions: How do you revise with friends?
What makes group revision effective?
Do you test each other?
suggestions: Create quiz questions for group sessions
Take turns being the 'teacher'

statements.statement: I allow myself time to be disappointed if something hasn't gone as well as I hoped, but I can move forward and make a list of what I need to improve

questions: How do you handle disappointment?
What helps you move forward after setbacks?
Do you make improvement plans?
suggestions: Allow 24 hours to process, then plan improvements
Write three specific actions after each setback

statements.statement: I can allow myself to be proud of what I have achieved, making a note of good news so I can return to it when I'm feeling less positive

questions: How do you celebrate achievements?
Do you keep a record of successes?
What are you proud of recently?
suggestions: Keep a 'wins journal' for tough days
Share achievements with someone supportive

statements.statement: I don't allow negative thoughts to dominate, I try to express them in a more positive way; 'one thing this teaches me is...' or 'I know now that next time I need to...' or 'mistakes give me information on how to improve...'

questions: How do you reframe negative thoughts?
What's your self-talk like after mistakes?
Can you find lessons in setbacks?
suggestions: Practice reframing statements daily
Write positive versions of negative thoughts

statements.statement: I expect to have setbacks, they are part of my learning process. I try and take responsibility for them rather than blame everyone else

questions: How do you view setbacks?
Who's responsible when things go wrong?
What do setbacks teach you?
suggestions: Normalize setbacks as learning opportunities
Ask 'what can I control?' in difficult situations

statements.statement: I find a group with students who are currently performing better than I am, as it gives me a chance to challenge myself when I try to match or beat them

questions: Who challenges you academically?
How do you use peer success as motivation?
What happens when you're the smartest in the room?
suggestions: Join study groups with high achievers
See peer success as inspiration, not intimidation

statements.statement: I generally focus on written feedback rather than the mark or grade alone

questions: Do you read all written feedback?
What matters more - grades or comments?
How do you use feedback?
suggestions: Read feedback before looking at grades
Act on one piece of feedback from each assignment

statements.statement: I generally keep trying on topics or questions I find hard, knowing that the longer I persist, the more likely I will succeed

questions: How long do you persist with difficult work?
What helps you keep trying?
When do you feel like giving up?
suggestions: Set persistence goals - 'try for 20 minutes before seeking help'
Track how persistence leads to breakthroughs

statements.statement: I have some tactics I use if I am feeling demotivated - go for a run, walk my dog, visit my friend, take a break

questions: What helps when you're demotivated?
What are your go-to mood boosters?
How do you reset when stuck?
suggestions: Create a 'motivation toolkit' list
Schedule regular breaks and rewards

statements.statement: I know constructive feedback is not an attack on my personality and this helps me action it rather than ignore it

questions: How do you separate feedback from personal criticism?
What helps you act on feedback?
When is feedback hardest to hear?
suggestions: View feedback as data, not judgment
Thank teachers for specific feedback

statements.statement: I know mistakes are information. I will give challenging work a go and try not to be afraid of making errors

questions: How do you view mistakes?
What have mistakes taught you?
What stops you from taking risks?
suggestions: Keep a 'lessons from mistakes' journal
Celebrate 'productive failures'

statements.statement: I know that sometimes, feedback is a reflection on my levels of effort or concentration. If I have to, I will accept I need to do more

questions: Can you be honest about your effort levels?
When do you need to do more?
How do you know if you're working hard enough?
suggestions: Rate your effort honestly after each task
Ask yourself: 'Did I really give my best?'

statements.statement: I read teacher feedback carefully and use this to re-draft work if I am unhappy with the grade

questions: Do you redraft work based on feedback?
How do you improve disappointing grades?
What stops you from redrafting?
suggestions: Ask teachers if you can resubmit improved work
Use feedback as a checklist for redrafts

statements.statement: I see my peers' strengths as an opportunity to learn from them, for example by asking to revise as a pair, swapping notes or checking someone else's work

questions: How do you learn from successful peers?
Who could you learn from?
What stops you from asking for peer help?
suggestions: Partner with someone strong in your weak areas
Ask to see exemplar work from peers

statements.statement: I seek help and support from peers and teachers when needed - I don't feel this is a sign of weakness

questions: How comfortable are you asking for help?
What stops you from seeking support?
Who can you turn to for help?
suggestions: Asking for help shows strength, not weakness
Identify your support network

statements.statement: I sometimes force myself to be positive, for example by listing three good things that have recently happened

questions: What are three good things from this week?
How do you shift to positive thinking?
When is positivity hardest?
suggestions: Daily gratitude practice - 3 good things
Share positives with a friend or family member

statements.statement: I try and be positive, help others be positive, and choose positive friends. When friends get overly negative I either tell them, or take a break from them

questions: How do your friends affect your attitude?
Can you set boundaries with negative people?
Who lifts you up?
suggestions: Surround yourself with positive influences
Practice kind but firm boundaries

statements.statement: I try not to feel embarrassed when I am praised, but accept the praise and reflect on why it was given

questions: How do you respond to praise?
What makes accepting praise difficult?
What does praise tell you?
suggestions: Practice saying 'thank you' to compliments
Reflect on what earned the praise

statements.statement: I use caring language and growth mindset to think about and discuss my learning; even when things have been hard I try not to criticise myself

questions: How do you talk to yourself about learning?
What language do you use after mistakes?
Would you talk to a friend that way?
suggestions: Replace 'I can't' with 'I can't yet'
Treat yourself with friend-like kindness

statements.statement: When I improve a score or mark, I take time to recognise what I did to achieve it - perhaps making a note so I can make sure I repeat my success

questions: What led to your recent improvements?
How do you replicate success?
Do you analyze what works?
suggestions: Keep a 'success strategies' list
Note what you did differently when you improve
